Tiny Volcano in the Gold Country overflows with possibilities 1 / 4 6414054|article-gallery-6414054|0 6414054|article-gallery-6414054|0 Sorry, lava lovers, there’s no volcano in Volcano, and there never was, but this tiny Gold Rush boom town in a crater-shaped valley near Jackson bubbles over with things to do.
In its Gold Rush peak, residents of this Amador County town numbered in the thousands — hard to imagine in a place that seems barely big enough to hold today’s population of just over 100. Tucked away north of Highway 88 and east of Highway 49, little Volcano has managed to remain much as it was in Gold Rush days. The Whiskey Flat Saloon is an honest-to-goodness old-time saloon. If you rode up and hitched your horse in front of the Volcano Country Store, no one would bat an eye.
California’s first theater company opened in Volcano in 1854 to entertain gold seekers. Over 160 years later, Volcano’s theater tradition still runs strong, with year-round productions by the Volcano Theatre Company. Spend your day exploring caves, hunting for swimming holes or shopping for antiques, but for the main attraction grab a bottle of Amador wine and head to the outdoor amphitheater for an unforgettable evening under the stars.
Why now? The warm evenings of summer in the Sierra foothills make for perfect play-watching weather. If you miss the summer season, you’re in for another treat: the changing green to red of the Shenandoah Valley vineyards in Amador wine country is one of the state’s most gush-worthy autumn sights, with or without a glass of local Zin in your hand.
Backstory: A stroll around Volcano takes only a few minutes, but it just might offer more commemorative plaques per mile than anywhere else in the state. Volcano had California’s first theater company and circulating library. The first astronomical observatory in the state was just up the hill. The Moose Milk cocktail was invented there (perhaps). There was even a little-known Civil War standoff in town settled (without bloodshed) by a 6-pound cannon named Old Abe.
The name Volcano may be misleading, but it certainly doesn’t lack for geological interest. The vast caves of Black Chasm Cavern National Natural Landmark and their many wondrous formations were discovered by gold prospectors in the 1850s, and early tours were given in the 1860s, but it wasn’t until 2001 that the cavern was properly opened up to the public. Today, it’s one of the main reasons travelers stumble across Volcano.
Checking in: The St. George Hotel is the first thing you see as you roll into town and the best place to roll out of bed in the morning. Built in 1862 (after the two previous hotels burned down) and one of California’s first three-story buildings, the hotel is charmingly creaky, with 14 rooms in the main building, six newer rooms in a rear addition, and two private suites hidden in the lush gardens.
For a unique camping experience that transports you back into California history, Indian Grinding Rock State Historic Park has seven traditional Miwok bark huts that hold up to six sleepers.
Spend your day: Start your day on the rocks with a cave tour of Black Chasm, either a basic walking tour or the longer Labyrinth Tour for those who like a physical challenge. Head back into the light, and stroll the shops and cafes of Sutter Creek.
There are wine tasting rooms right in town, but it’s worth a drive through the Shenandoah Valley vineyards out of Plymouth even if you’re not a wine lover.
Wind back to Volcano by the back roads, and you’ll still have time to take in dinner and a show at the Volcano Theatre Company.
Dining: The Volcano Union Inn & Pub is the place to head for evening grub. The sister restaurant in nearby Plymouth, Taste, is one of the top fine-dining destinations in Amador County. The food is more low-key at the Union, but the pedigree comes through. For a nightcap (or an anytime-cap), a visit to the Whiskey Flat Saloon is a must.
Don’t miss: Ice cream lovers will come from hours away just to sample the frozen delights at Munnerlyn’s Ice Creamery just up the hill in Pine Grove, a tiny shop with artisanal ice cream and creative flavors that would draw rave reviews in any major city, but without a sprinkle of snobbery.
Don’t bother: Unless ducking into cramped, dusty holes is your hobby, don’t get drawn in by the signs to the Masonic Cave. It’s free, but you still might want your money back. The real cave is just down the road at Black Chasm.
Word to the wise: Summer weekends at the St. George Hotel are wedding territory, so book early, go during the week, or try the Union Inn & Pub.
Andy Murdock is a freelance writer in Alameda. E-mail: travel@sfchronicle.com Twitter: @andy_murdock
If you go
GETTING THERE
Volcano is northeast of Jackson, 3 miles north of Highway 88 from Pine Grove, about three hours from San Francisco.
WHERE TO STAY
St. George Hotel: 16104 Main St., Volcano, (209) 296-4458, www.stgeorgevolcano.com. Historic hotel with rooms in the main building (many with shared baths), newer en-suite rooms in the rear annex, and private cottages in the garden. Rates start at $55 per night including breakfast, cottages from $175 per night.
Volcano Union Inn: 21375 Consolation St., Volcano, (209) 296-7711, www.volcanounion.com. A four-room bed and breakfast with private baths and full breakfasts. Rates start at $85 per night.
Indian Grinding Rock State Historic Park: 14881 Pine Grove Volcano Road, Pine Grove, (209) 296-7488, www.parks.ca.gov/?page_id=553. Indian historic site with a shaded 22-site campground, $30 per night. Miwok U’macha’tam’ma’ bark houses can be reserved up to six months in advance, $85 per night for up to six people.
WHERE TO EAT
Volcano Union Inn: (See above.) Gastropub with simple but gourmet fare and a wide array of beers. Dinner Thursday-Monday, lunch on weekends. Entrees: $12-$28.
St. George Hotel & Whiskey Flat Saloon: (See above.) Classic American dinner fare in the hotel’s charming parlor, Thursday-Sunday, lunch on weekends and brunch on Sunday. Entrees: $18-$30. Saloon open evenings, Wednesday-Sunday.
Munnerlyn’s Ice Creamery: 20145 Hwy 88, Pine Grove, (209) 296-4400. Remarkable homemade ice creams in creative and seasonal flavors. Closed Tuesdays.
WHAT TO DO
Volcano Theatre Company: 16121 Main St., Volcano, (209) 419-0744, www.volcanotheatreofvolcanoca.com. Shows year-round on Friday and Saturday. Bring your own food and wine for outdoor shows. Tickets $16.
Black Chasm Cavern National Natural Landmark: 15701 Pioneer-Volcano Road, Volcano, (866) 762-2837, www.caverntours.com/BlackRt.htm. 50-minute walking tour of the cave, $15.95. A challenging three-hour Labyrinth Tour is offered for $79. Gemstone mining and gold panning activities also offered daily.
MORE INFORMATION
Amador Council of Tourism: www.touramador.com.
Amador Vintners Association: www.amadorwine .com.
